page.title: 02NATURAL FEATURES MITCHELDEAN
page.content: Mitcheldean lies in a valley 500 feet above sea level on the north eastern edge of the Forest of Dean. The upfold of the Silurian Rocks of May Hill to the north east of the block has caused all the rock beds around Mitcheldean to become steeply inclined to the west. The result is a landscape of parallel Old Red Sandstone ridges and Devonian Red Marl valleys. Immediately to the west of Mitcheldean itself, a steep, cliff-like escarpment of Quartz Conglomerate leads to high ground formed of Carboniferous Limestone, rising to over 800 feet above sea level, the highest ground in the area. West of this the sandstones and shales of the Coal Measures form the rolling plateau of the Forest of Dean, which stretches away south westwards.
